Denitrificimonas halotolerans is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Proteobacteria. It is a facultatively anaerobic, Gram-negative, rod-shaped microorganism. Denitrificimonas halotolerans is capable of denitrification, a process in which nitrate or nitrite is converted to gaseous nitrogen compounds, such as nitric oxide, nitrous oxide, or dinitrogen, as the terminal electron acceptor during anaerobic respiration.

This species is halotolerant, meaning it can grow in the presence of relatively high concentrations of salt. It has been isolated from various saline environments, including seawater, hypersaline lakes, and saline soils. Denitrificimonas halotolerans is capable of utilizing a range of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, and it plays a role in the nitrogen cycle in saline habitats by contributing to the removal of nitrate and nitrite through denitrification.
